âœ‚ï¸Â CSS text-box-trim â€” This handy property lets you finely control the leading space found both above and below text. Adam shows us how it works, and what problems it solves. Itâ€™s in Chrome/Edge 133 and Safari 18.2, no Firefox support justÂ yet.

Adam Argyle

'WordPress Is in Trouble' â€” The continuing WordPress drama leaves a huge question mark on the overall project and the potential wide-ranging implications for the open web. Thereâ€™s been a lot of chatter recently about a possible fork, but thatâ€™s already hit a Mullenweg-shaped roadblock. This story is far fromÂ over (if you want to get up to speed on things, this is a handy, detailed timeline of events).

Gavin Anderegg

âš–ï¸ WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg has said lawsuits may "force the closure of WordPress.org". Also, project-steward Automattic is reducing its sponsored contributions to the WordPress project.

Write CSS Like a Pro â€” Kevin Powell shares how to create a responsive website from scratch using modern CSS features (such as nesting, utility classes, custom properties, and more). This detailed video course also dives into adding additional polish via animations, view transitions, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Tight Mode: Why Browsers Produce Different PerformanceÂ Results â€” This post offers a high-level look at what â€˜Tight Modeâ€™ is and how it influences the way the web works. If, like me, this was new to you, itâ€™s a function which constrains what resources are loaded and in whatÂ order.

Geoff Graham

The Success of Interop 2024 â€” A positive look back at what this collaborative cross-browser effort achieved in the past year â€”Â in particular the 95% interoperability reached across the key focus areas by end of 2024. Nice to see the ongoing results of working together for the benefit of the web platform at large. Interop 2025 plans areÂ underway.

Jen Simmons (WebKit)

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • ğŸ™ Both Eric Meyer and Chris Coyier have shared their wish lists of CSS features and changes they'd like to see in 2025.

  • ğŸ¤ Google is partnering up with The Linux Foundation to launch an initiative called Supporters of Chromium-based Browsers, a more open way to foster collaboration on the myriad of Chrome/Chromium-based browsers availableÂ today.

ğŸ“™ Articles & Tutorials

Double-Keyed Caching: How Browser Cache Partitioning Changed the Web â€” In the name of privacy, browsers have now shifted from single-keyed to double-keyed caching (based around both the target URL and source origin). Hereâ€™s a good overview of the pros and cons introduced as result, withÂ Addy explaining this complex change in detail, noting how it reduces cross-site tracking, impacts both performance and bandwidth, CDN use andÂ more.

Addy Osmani

You Might Not Have a Web Performance Problem â€” Some caution and caveats to consider when it comes to Lighthouse results and the performance picture they canÂ paint.

Matt Zeunert

Sentry sponsor

Assumes zero knowledge so, although entertaining and beneficial enough for us all, is perfect for a beginner â€” one to pass along to those startingÂ out.

Kevin Powell beginner

A Couple of CSS Tricks for HTML dialog Elements â€” Namely blurring the dialogâ€™s backdrop and disabling page scrolling when a dialog isÂ open.

Cassidy Williams

Running Animations Without Keyframes â€” Supported in most browsers, @starting-style provides a way to define starting values for transitions meaning no keyframes areÂ needed.

Temani Afif

Chris Coyier

Om Malik

ğŸ§° Tools & Resources

Easing Wizard: A CSS Easings Editor and Generator â€” Weâ€™ve shared tools like this before, but this one might be the best-designed one yet. You can copy the code as CSS or Tailwind and thereâ€™s an option to deep link to the current easing configÂ settings.

Matthias Martin

Protect Against Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting â€” stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

Open Props UI â€” A CSS UI library exploring how next-gen HTML & CSS features can change the way we create components. Version 1.0 hit yesterday, adding a ton of components. RepoÂ here.

Felix B

Comic Mono â€” A legible monospace font (see image above) based on that very typeface weâ€™ve all been trained to recognize since childhood. Available in a regular and boldÂ weight. Is your editor ready forÂ this..?

Thai Pangsakulyanont

ARIA DevTools: A Chrome Extension to Easily Spot Missing ARIA Labels and Roles â€” Provides a visualization of a websiteâ€™s accessibility tree, so you can see where you might need to add ARIA-basedÂ landmarks.

Mateusz ZieliÅ„ski

Photo Gradient: An Online Tool to Generate & Customize Mesh Gradients From Any Image â€” The download is in PNG format and you can also just randomly generate and edit mesh gradients without uploading anÂ image.

Daniel Destefanis

tailwind-to-inline: Transform Tailwind Classes to Inline Styles â€” This is an npm script you can run on your Tailwind-based templates should you want to convert them to inline styles, such as for use in HTMLÂ emails.

items.title: Here's what went down in 2024
items.content:
ğŸš€ Frontend Focus

#â€‹673 â€” December 18, 2024 | Read on the web

âœï¸ Hello, and welcome to the last issue of Frontend Focus for 2024! It's been a packed year for the web platform, with plenty of exciting new features added to our developer toolbelt, improvements in browser cooperation, the developing AI tooling situation, and much more. As ever, we're going to take a look back over what we've shared in Frontend Focus throughout 2024 and revisit some of the highlights â€”Â you'll no doubt find something that's well worth bookmarking, sharing on, or revisiting (or maybe you missed it the firstÂ time).

If you've enjoyed the newsletter and found it valuable this year, please consider following us on Bluesky, and maybe forwarding this on to a friend â€”Â perhaps even someone starting their frontend journey in the new year. A big thanks for reading. We'll be back in your inbox in early January. Now, it's a big issue, so let's get started!
__
Your editors, ğŸ¦‹ Chris Brandrick & Peter Cooper

ğŸ—“ï¸ Top Ten of 2024

01:Â Twelve Modern CSS One-Line Upgrades â€” Stephanie shared this list of a dozen CSS properties that are well worth knowing earlier in the year â€” the one-line upgrades here will help reduce technical debt, remove unnecessary lines of JavaScript, and score some easy wins for the user experience, too.

Stephanie Eckles

Complete Intro to React v9: New Project, Modern Stack â€” Join Brian Holt in building a pizza delivery app from scratch. Master hooks, TanStack Router, testing, and React 19 features in this comprehensive guide to modern React development. No prior React experienceÂ needed.

Frontend Masters sponsor

02:Â Five CSS Snippets Every Frontend Developer Should Know in 2024 â€” Adam did this in 2023, and the 2024 version proved very popular too. All the snippets here are toolbelt worthy, powerful, CSS tips (including nesting, sub grid, container query units, etc) that will be just as valuable as we head into 2025.

Adam Argyle

03:Â Inline Conditionals in CSS? â€” In the summer the CSS Working Group resolved to add an inline if() to CSS. An exciting step for CSS, but one that raises lots of questions too. This explainer from Lea proved valuable for many.

Lea Verou

04:Â What You Need to Know about Modern CSS â€” A bookmarkable guide from this past Spring featuring a list of all the then new additions to CSS (think nesting, view transitions, :has(), etc). It remains really handy, as thereâ€™s an explainer, demo, code example, and a quick bit of detail as to why you should care about eachÂ entry. If you want to scrub up on what new CSS features we've gotten this year, this ain't a bad place to look.

Chris Coyier

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

Here's just a few quick snippets of things that went down in the world of Frontend this year:

  • ğŸ’¨ There was plenty of continued steam behind the efforts to get a formal solution in place for CSS masonry.
  • âš™ï¸ It was a big year for Web Components and our shared understanding and utilization of them.
  • ğŸ—“ï¸ The Web turned 35 â€” here's what Sir Tim Berners-Lee had to say.
  • ğŸ Apple announced significant changes to iOS, Safari, and the App Store for those in the European Union.
  • ğŸ“± ...and as part of those changes, came a fight on the future of PWAs on iOS.
  • ğŸª Google changed the deprecation timeline for third-party cookies...again. The W3C had thoughts...
  • ğŸ˜¬ WordPress got into a scrap with WP Engine, and it got messy.
  • ğŸ—³ï¸ We got the results from the 2024 State of CSS, and State of HTML surveys, plus as of just yesterday the 2024 edition of the State of JS dropped.
  • ğŸŸª CSS got it's own logo! Goodbye CSS3 shield. ğŸ«¡
  • ğŸ“‘ The excellent, comprehensive Web Almanac returned to summise the year, sharing the state of the web in 2024.

05:Â How to Center a Div â€” The fact that so many of you tapped on this one tells us that it's still something of a tricky ordeal to get right. Yes, it's easier now thanks to new tools (Flex, Grid, etc), but which to use? Josh shares the trade-offs between different approaches, and the best strategies to use.

Josh W Comeau

06:Â The Magic of Clip Path â€” This post sets out to â€œinspire you and show you that thinking outside the box can lead to some great animationsâ€ â€” all via the magic of the very powerful clip-path CSSÂ property.

Emil Kowalski

AuthKit: The Worldâ€™s Best Login Box â€” Powered by WorkOS & Radix â€” AuthKit is a complete solution for authentication, authorization, and user management. Itâ€™s free up to 1 million MAUs and comes standard with RBAC, bot protection, MFA, andÂ more.

AuthKit sponsor

07:Â CSS Selectors â€” A thorough, complete guide covering all of the various methods we have to select elements in CSS (such as pseudo-selectors, nested selectors, attribute selectors, etc) and how to use them for applyingÂ styles.

Geoff Graham

08:Â An Interactive Guide to CSS Container Queries â€” This is a detailed explainer on CSS container queries, exploring the problems they solve, how they work, and how we can use them in our workflows. Lots of code and visuals to help things along too. Well worthÂ bookmarking.

Ahmad Shadeed

ğŸ’¡ Josh Comeau also took a look at Container Queries this year, noting that adoption so far isn't all that high. Here he goes into why that may be, reintroduces us to the feature, and suggests how we may want to approach using it.

09:Â How to Make Your Web Page Faster Before It Even Loads â€” Salma looked at the events that happen before the first byte of a web page is even received by the browser. Asking if we can measure those events, and subsequently optimize them to make our web pages and applications load evenÂ faster. Neat.

Salma Alam-Naylor

10:Â The Frontend Developer/Engineer Handbook 2024 â€” This incredibly in-depth and detailed guide on the current web development landscape was well received. It's remains a superb resource for getting up to speed on everything from code editors, CSS, UX, UI, the command line, performance, accessibility, testing, AI, and much, muchÂ more.

Cody Lindley

ğŸ§° Popular Tools & Resources we shared this year

Anchor Position Tool â€” CSS anchor positioning is on the way, and one rather neat layout mechanism thatâ€™s part of the spec is position-area. This (Chromium 129+ only) demo from Una demonstrates how it works. There was plenty of interest in this one, and although it's still in draft, it should prove rather powerful once widelyÂ available.

Una Kravets

Speedometer 3.0: A Browser Benchmark for Webapp Responsiveness â€” 2024 gave us a new major release of Speedometer â€” the first with a cross-industry collaborative approach supported by each major browser engine (Blink, Gecko, WebKit). Version 3 added in many new tests, performance wins, and improvements. You can run the test for yourselfÂ here.

Apple, Google, Microsoft, and Mozilla

CSS Grid Generator â€” This handy browser-based tool got plenty of you clicking â€”Â you can use it to easily create custom CSS grid layouts â€” you can specify the number of columns, rows, and gutterÂ size.

Kristjan Retter

A Showcase of What's Now Possible with Progressive Web Apps
Danny Moerkerke

Jake's 'Slightly More Opinionated' Modern CSS Reset
Jake Lazaroff

Barba.js: Create Smooth Visual Transitions Between Pages
De Rosa, Michel, et al.

Plain Vanilla: A Tutorial Website for Modern, Vanilla Web Development
Joeri Sebrechts

PixiJS v8: A Library For Building Striking 2D WebGL Experiences
PixiJS Team

ğŸ¦‹ Frontend on Bluesky

...and finally, this year has seen plenty of folks make the jump over to Bluesky for talking all things frontend. To help things along, we created a handy list that brings together some of the voices that you may want to hear from. It's proven useful for many, so I'm sharing it here again to sign off the year with. See you in 2025!

Ipx.
